articles.headline: In Britain, Rising Prices and Shortages Evoke 1970s-Style Jitters
articles.snippet: The nation’s economy is very different from the bleak days of the 70s, but certain parallels are unnerving Britons and loom as a potential headache for Prime Minister Boris Johnson.
articles.abstract: The nation’s economy is very different from the bleak days of the 70s, but certain parallels are unnerving Britons and loom as a potential headache for Prime Minister Boris Johnson.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Long lines at gas stations, rising fuel prices, empty shelves in supermarkets and worries about runaway inflation.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler, Eshe Nelson and Jenny Gross

articles.headline: States Begin a Complex Booster Shot Rollout for Pfizer Recipients
articles.snippet: Health officials were preparing on Friday to start giving booster shots to older and at-risk Americans, trying to make sense of new and broad eligibility guidelines.
articles.abstract: Health officials were preparing on Friday to start giving booster shots to older and at-risk Americans, trying to make sense of new and broad eligibility guidelines.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — State health officials rushed on Friday to roll out campaigns to provide coronavirus booster shots for millions of vulnerable people who got the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine and to help a confused public understand who qualifies for the extra shots.
articles.byline: By Noah Weiland, Reed Abelson and Jan Hoffman

articles.headline: U.S. Agrees to Release Huawei Executive in Case That Strained Ties With China
articles.snippet: China reciprocated within hours, freeing two Canadians, a notable resolution in a relationship that has been spiraling downward.
articles.abstract: China reciprocated within hours, freeing two Canadians, a notable resolution in a relationship that has been spiraling downward.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department reached an agreement on Friday clearing the way for a senior executive of Huawei Technologies, the Chinese telecommunications giant, to return to China after admitting some wrongdoing in a sanctions violation case, removing one major irritant between the two superpowers.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger, Dan Bilefsky and Katie Benner

articles.headline: Robinhood Hits Campus, Where Credit Card Companies Fear to Tread
articles.snippet: The company plans to hit up college coffee shops to spread the word about its services. When credit card companies did it a generation ago, Congress got involved.
articles.abstract: The company plans to hit up college coffee shops to spread the word about its services. When credit card companies did it a generation ago, Congress got involved.
articles.lead_paragraph: Robinhood, the free stock-trading app with 21 million active users and counting, is about to hit the road for a college coffeehouse tour to drum up new customers.

articles.headline: Among Those Who Marched Into the Capitol on Jan. 6: An F.B.I. Informant
articles.snippet: A member of the far-right Proud Boys texted his F.B.I. handler during the assault, but maintained the group had no plan in advance to enter the Capitol and disrupt the election certification.
articles.abstract: A member of the far-right Proud Boys texted his F.B.I. handler during the assault, but maintained the group had no plan in advance to enter the Capitol and disrupt the election certification.
articles.lead_paragraph: As scores of Proud Boys made their way, chanting and shouting, toward the Capitol on Jan. 6, one member of the far-right group was busy texting a real-time account of the march.
articles.byline: By Alan Feuer and Adam Goldman

articles.headline: Want a Can’t Miss Productivity Tip? Forget About Being Productive.
articles.snippet: People and industries measure how productive they are in similar ways. This extended period of remote work for many has revealed how flawed that can be.
articles.abstract: People and industries measure how productive they are in similar ways. This extended period of remote work for many has revealed how flawed that can be.
articles.lead_paragraph: How productive was your day?

articles.headline: Long Hours, Low Pay, Loneliness and a Booming Industry
articles.snippet: The ranks of home health aides are expected to grow more than any other job in the next decade. What kind of work are they being asked to do?
articles.abstract: The ranks of home health aides are expected to grow more than any other job in the next decade. What kind of work are they being asked to do?
articles.lead_paragraph: For 15 years, Yvette Dessin spent long work days with her elderly patients, accompanying them on walks, cooking them meals and bathing those who needed that most intimate kind of care. If a patient died, Ms. Dessin and her adult daughter attended the funeral services to pay their respects.
articles.byline: By Liz Donovan and Muriel Alarcón

articles.headline: Affluent, Anxious and Almost Normal: A Journey Through Merkel’s Germany
articles.snippet: As Angela Merkel prepares to step down after 16 years as chancellor of Germany, she leaves behind a country profoundly changed — and anxious about changing more.
articles.abstract: As Angela Merkel prepares to step down after 16 years as chancellor of Germany, she leaves behind a country profoundly changed — and anxious about changing more.
articles.lead_paragraph: STUTTGART, Germany — The small silver star at the tip of Aleksandar Djordjevic’s Mercedes shines bright. He polishes it every week.

articles.headline: Democrats’ Spending Fight Carries High Stakes for Their Candidates
articles.snippet: Failure of moderates and progressives to reach a deal would fuel Republican attacks on their competence — with consequences as soon as November in Virginia, and in the midterms next year.
articles.abstract: Failure of moderates and progressives to reach a deal would fuel Republican attacks on their competence — with consequences as soon as November in Virginia, and in the midterms next year.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With President Biden’s approval ratings falling below 50 percent after the most trying stretch of his young administration, pushing through his ambitious legislative agenda has taken on a new urgency for Democratic lawmakers.

articles.headline: They Investigate Police Killings. Their Record Is Wanting.
articles.snippet: After the murder of George Floyd, some states looked to independent agencies to examine deaths in police custody. But dozens of cases handled by the Texas Rangers show the approach has flaws.
articles.abstract: After the murder of George Floyd, some states looked to independent agencies to examine deaths in police custody. But dozens of cases handled by the Texas Rangers show the approach has flaws.
articles.lead_paragraph: When the Texas Rangers learned that a woman had died in a jail south of Dallas, they put Adam Russell on the case.
articles.byline: By Michael LaForgia and Jennifer Valentino-DeVries

articles.headline: The Marines Reluctantly Let a Sikh Officer Wear a Turban. He Says It’s Not Enough.
articles.snippet: While other armed services allow some religion-based exceptions to dress standards without problems, the Marines insist that even small deviations can threaten the force’s effectiveness.
articles.abstract: While other armed services allow some religion-based exceptions to dress standards without problems, the Marines insist that even small deviations can threaten the force’s effectiveness.
articles.lead_paragraph: Almost every morning for five years, First Lt. Sukhbir Toor has pulled on the uniform of the United States Marine Corps. On Thursday, he also got to put on the turban of a faithful Sikh.

articles.headline: New Limits Give Chinese Video Gamers Whiplash
articles.snippet: China has a complex relationship with video games. New government rules for minors have made it even more so.
articles.abstract: China has a complex relationship with video games. New government rules for minors have made it even more so.
articles.lead_paragraph: China’s video game industry is booming. But it sure doesn’t feel that way to Stone Shi, a game designer in China.
articles.byline: By Paul Mozur and Elsie Chen

articles.headline: With Abortion Largely Banned in Texas, an Oklahoma Clinic Is Inundated
articles.snippet: The new law prohibits abortions after about six weeks, a very early stage of pregnancy. Many women are now traveling out of state for the procedure.
articles.abstract: The new law prohibits abortions after about six weeks, a very early stage of pregnancy. Many women are now traveling out of state for the procedure.
articles.lead_paragraph: OKLAHOMA CITY — On a windy Tuesday morning, the parking lot outside a small brick building on the Southside of Oklahoma City was filling up fast. The first to arrive, a red truck shortly before 8 a.m., was from Texas. So was the second and the third.

articles.headline: How China Plans to Avert an Evergrande Financial Crisis
articles.snippet: Control of the banking system gives Beijing the tools to stop a broader collapse, officials believe, while censorship and police powers can stifle protests.
articles.abstract: Control of the banking system gives Beijing the tools to stop a broader collapse, officials believe, while censorship and police powers can stifle protests.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — In any other country, the sudden collapse of a corporate titan with more than $300 billion in debt would send shock waves across the economy. Headlines would blare. Banks would shudder. Investors would panic.

articles.headline: America’s Need to Pay Its Bills Has Spawned a Political Game
articles.snippet: Republicans and Democrats have long sparred over raising the debt ceiling. But this time, the odds are growing that the U.S. could default.
articles.abstract: Republicans and Democrats have long sparred over raising the debt ceiling. But this time, the odds are growing that the U.S. could default.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For nearly two decades, lawmakers in Washington have waged an escalating display of brinkmanship over the federal government’s ability to borrow money to pay its bills. They have forced administrations of both parties to take evasive actions, pushing the nation dangerously close to economic calamity. But they have never actually tipped the United States into default.

articles.headline: German Election Heralds Messier Politics and Weaker Leadership After Merkel
articles.snippet: Preliminary results indicated an outcome so tight that it could take months of talks to form a new government at a critical moment for Europe.
articles.abstract: Preliminary results indicated an outcome so tight that it could take months of talks to form a new government at a critical moment for Europe.
articles.lead_paragraph: BERLIN — After 16 years of Angela Merkel as their chancellor, Germans scattered their votes across the political spectrum on Sunday in the election to replace her, a fractured return that heralds a messier political era in Germany and weaker German leadership in Europe.

articles.headline: Goldman Sachs, Ozy Media and a $40 Million Conference Call Gone Wrong
articles.snippet: The digital media company has raised eyebrows for its claims about its audience size for years. Then came the strange voice on the phone.
articles.abstract: The digital media company has raised eyebrows for its claims about its audience size for years. Then came the strange voice on the phone.
articles.lead_paragraph: This past winter, Goldman Sachs was closing in on a $40 million investment in Ozy, a digital media company founded in 2013, and there seemed to be a lot of reasons to do the deal. Ozy boasted of a large audience for its general interest website, its newsletters and its videos, and the company had a charismatic chief executive, Carlos Watson, a onetime cable news anchor who had worked at Goldman Sachs early in his career. And, crucially, Ozy said it had a great relationship with YouTube, where many of its videos attracted more than a million views.

articles.headline: Scotland’s Oil Industry Is Fading as Wind Energy Beckons
articles.snippet: Oil and gas production in the North Sea is not the economic juggernaut it once was. Can floating wind turbines offer an alternative?
articles.abstract: Oil and gas production in the North Sea is not the economic juggernaut it once was. Can floating wind turbines offer an alternative?
articles.lead_paragraph: ABERDEEN, Scotland — It’s easy to see how vital oil is to Aberdeen, a venerable port city on Scotland’s northeast coast. Step out the door of the small international airport and you are buffeted from across the road by the roar of helicopters ferrying crews back and forth to oil platforms scattered across the North Sea.

articles.headline: ‘Every Day Is Frightening’: Working for the Top U.S. Employer Amid Covid
articles.snippet: As offices debate the merits and logistics of reopening, a parallel sphere of workers like Peter Naughton, a Walmart cashier, seem to inhabit another world. Often their jobs just got really hard.
articles.abstract: As offices debate the merits and logistics of reopening, a parallel sphere of workers like Peter Naughton, a Walmart cashier, seem to inhabit another world. Often their jobs just got really hard.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was a hot morning in Baton Rouge, La., the day that Peter Naughton woke up on the floor.

articles.headline: Facebook Delays Instagram App for Users 13 and Younger
articles.snippet: The social media giant said it still wanted to build a child-focused Instagram product but would postpone the plans in the face of criticism.
articles.abstract: The social media giant said it still wanted to build a child-focused Instagram product but would postpone the plans in the face of criticism.
articles.lead_paragraph: Facebook said on Monday that it had paused development of an Instagram Kids service that would be tailored for children 13 years old or younger, as the social network increasingly faces questions about the app’s effect on young people’s mental health.
articles.byline: By Adam Satariano and Ryan Mac

articles.headline: Power Outages Hit China, Threatening the Economy and Christmas
articles.snippet: High demand and soaring energy prices have forced some factories to shut down, adding further problems for already snarled global supply chains.
articles.abstract: High demand and soaring energy prices have forced some factories to shut down, adding further problems for already snarled global supply chains.
articles.lead_paragraph: DONGGUAN, China — Power cuts and even blackouts have slowed or closed factories across China in recent days, adding a new threat to the country’s slowing economy and potentially further snarling global supply chains ahead of the busy Christmas shopping season in the West.

articles.headline: Murders Spiked in 2020 in Cities Across the United States
articles.snippet: The year-to-year increase in homicides from 2019 was the largest since national record-keeping began in 1960. But overall, major crimes declined last year.
articles.abstract: The year-to-year increase in homicides from 2019 was the largest since national record-keeping began in 1960. But overall, major crimes declined last year.
articles.lead_paragraph: The United States experienced its biggest one-year increase on record in homicides in 2020, according to new figures released on Monday by the F.B.I., with some cities hitting record highs.
